awd_titl_txt: Molecular interactions between rhizobacteria and wheat under water stress
awd_abstract_narration:
Over 30% of the earth's surface is arid, and most climate change models predict future increases in drought length and severity that will adversely affect plant life. Plants adapt to water deprivation in part by fostering root-associated microorganisms that enhance resistance to environmental stresses. The impact of water limitation on molecular communication and the interactions between plants and their associated microbes remains poorly understood. This project will utilize a combination of analytical chemistry, bioinformatics, genetic, and physiological approaches to investigate the mutually beneficial interaction between the root-colonizing bacterium, Pseudomonas synxantha, and wheat under arid conditions. The research will yield new insights into how plants in dry soils recruit, shape, and manipulate their associated microbes to mitigate drought stress. This project will train graduate students and a postdoctoral scholar that will be engaged in all aspects of the research. The analysis of bacterial metabolic pathways will be done by undergraduates via individual research projects and as a part of microbial genetics and ecology classes. The project team will participate in university programs and coordinate outreach activities aimed at recruiting underrepresented groups into the sciences and strengthening science education at the elementary through college levels. This research is crucial for exploitation of beneficial microbial communities to improve crop performance and complement plant breeding efforts.

An overarching goal of this application is to understand at the molecular level how root-colonizing (rhizosphere) bacteria maintain physiological activity and tight mutualistic interactions with their plant hosts in dry soils. Plants can be viewed as meta-organisms or holobionts that rely in part on their microbiome for specific functions and traits. Recent studies have highlighted the essential role of beneficial rhizobacteria in the ability of plants to tolerate abiotic stresses, including drought. However, the effect of water limitation on the plant-microbe communication in the rhizosphere remains virtually unexplored. The approach focuses on Pseudomonas synxantha 2-79, a model biocontrol strain that is naturally adapted to wheat grown in arid parts of the Pacific Northwest. The specific aims are to characterize the changes in wheat root exudates that are associated with water stress and to relate these changes to the physiology of 2-79; to identify transcriptional responses in 2-79 to water-stressed conditions using RNA-seq; and to define the contribution of selected pathways to the ability of 2-79 to persist on roots under conditions of water deficit. The expected results will help to understand how rhizodeposition in arid soils modulates bacterial pathways involved in the mitigation of drought stress and contributes to the selection of specific types of beneficial rhizobacteria. The project will also provide a crucial functional genomics complement to ongoing field studies aimed at deciphering the effect of soil moisture on the rhizosphere microbiome of dryland wheat.

por.por_cntn:
Over 30% of the earth’s surface is arid, and most models of climate change predict future increases in drought length and severity. Plants have developed various biochemical and physiological mechanisms to respond and adapt to the deprivation of water. One of them is the fostering of root-associated microbial communities that enhance the ability of plants to resist abiotic stresses by stimulating nutrient uptake and organ development, suppressing pathogens and modulating stress phytohormone levels. There is mounting evidence that stressed plants actively recruit and shape their beneficial microbiome by secreting photosynthetically fixed carbon into the soil that directly surrounds plant roots in the form of root exudates. However, many details of this process remain poorly understood.

 

To address this gap, we performed a metabolomic analysis of root exudates of wheat and barley and their wild relative, the model monocot plant Brachypodium distachyon. We then studied how these exudates are metabolized by several strains of the P. fluorescens group, including Pseudomonas synxantha 2-79, a biocontrol strain naturally adapted to wheat grown in arid parts of the Pacific Northwest. The amendment of bacterial cultures with root exudates altered expression of multiple genes encoding catabolic and anabolic enzymes, predicted transporters, transcriptional regulators, stress response, and conserved hypothetical proteins. In most strains, these differentially expressed genes were almost equally split between the core and variable genome regions, mirroring the substantial strain-to-strain variation in the genome size and gene content within the P. fluorescens species complex. We suggest that such variably distributed pathways contribute to the differential affinity of rhizobacteria towards host plants and/or to determine which species flourish in response to growing roots and changing environments. Other differentially expressed genes were highly conserved and may represent cellular pathways that are important for survival in soil- and plant-associated habitats.

We also demonstrated that exposure to water stress significantly alters the amounts of primary metabolites exuded by wheat roots. We observed shifts in the levels of multiple carbohydrates, amino acids, organic acids and their derivatives. These changes were mirrored by transcriptome changes in P. synxantha 2-79 cultured in the presence of exudates collected from control and stressed plants. Among genes strongly induced by water-stressed exudates were those involved in the uptake and catabolism of quaternary amines (QACs). This observation was supported by the significantly higher levels of choline and glycine betaine in the root secretions of water-stressed wheat. These compounds act as osmolytes and osmoprotectants that mediate response to drought, salinity, and other abiotic stresses both in plants and microorganisms.

Pseudomonads do not synthesize QACs de novo but have evolved a network of pathways to scavenge these compounds from eukaryotic hosts, where these metabolites are abundant due to the prominence of phosphatidylcholine in cellular membranes. Pseudomonas synxantha 2-79 carries genes for the conversion of choline, carnitine, and glycine betaine to glycine, as well as quaternary amine transporters of the BCCT and ABC families. Under water-replete conditions, 2-79 uses plant-derived QACs as a source of nutrients. In contrast, under water stress, the QACs choline, betaine, and carnitine are accumulated for osmoprotection. Under drought stress, a 2-79 mutant devoid of all known QAC transporters was less competitive in the colonization of the plant rhizosphere than its wild-type parental strain, suggesting an essential role of root exudates in the ability of rhizobacteria to adapt and persist on roots of drought-stressed plants.

Our findings provide an example of a mechanism through which stressed plants actively recruit and shape their microbiomes by varying the amounts and chemical profiles of photosynthetically fixed carbon deposited into the soil directly surrounding plant roots. More broadly, our results help to better understand complex feedbacks between plants and associated microbes, which is crucially important for our ability to harness the rhizosphere microbiome for maximizing yields and crop resilience to drought, salinity, and other forms of abiotic and biotic stress. These findings also contribute to the understanding of microorganism-driven carbon sequestration in the rhizosphere, a process that plays an important role in ecosystem functioning and nutrient cycling in terrestrial ecosystems.
